Issues Correctly Identified by the AI.Analysis: AI proposed expanding the 'Recipients' definition to include several roles like consultants and shareholders. HR implemented a partial expansion, adding 'shareholders' and 'potential syndicate members', confirming the AI's core finding.

Issues Correctly Identified by the AI.Issue: Return & Destruction of Information clause missing exceptions
Issues Correctly Identified by the AI.Analysis: AI proposed adding exceptions for information retained in automated backups, for legal compliance, and in internal work product. HR implemented these exact exceptions, fully adopting the AI's suggestion.

AI proposed reducing the non-solicit term and adding several exceptions, including for portfolio companies. HR reduced the term from 24 to 12 months and broadened the general advertisement exception, but did not add the key portfolio company carve-out.

AI proposed changing the strict liability standard for representatives to a 'best efforts' standard per Policy 13. HR implemented this change by replacing 'cause' with 'use its best efforts to cause' in the related no-contact clause.
AI proposed changing the governing law from Dutch to Belgian and jurisdiction from Amsterdam to Antwerp, per playbook preference. HR implemented this change exactly as suggested.

Issues Missed by the AI.Analysis: AI did not mention this. HR flagged an added clause that creates a loophole, allowing Representatives to be exempted from the Undertaking's obligations, which weakens our position.
AI did not mention this. HR flagged the addition of a 'No Commitment' clause, which violates Policy 8's instruction not to add such a clause if one is not already present.
AI did not mention this. HR identified and deleted a redundant clause that was functionally equivalent to a 'No Commitment' clause, aligning with the playbook's preference for concise agreements.

Issues Flagged by AI but Not Addressed b.Analysis: AI flagged the complete absence of a limitation of liability clause, a critical protection required by Policy 1. HR did not add this clause, leaving the company exposed to unlimited liability.
AI flagged the non-solicitation of suppliers and customers as overly broad, suggesting it be narrowed to key representatives. This issue was not addressed in the HR edits.

AI flagged that the no-contact clause was too broad, restricting contact with former employees and shareholders. HR edited this section to reduce the term but did not narrow the scope of restricted persons as the AI suggested.
AI flagged that the definition of Confidential Information was missing standard market exceptions. This issue was not addressed by HR, leaving the definition narrower than is standard.

High Priority.citation: The Undersigned, each of its holding companies and subsidiaries... and their officers, directors, employees, professional advisers, providers of finance, and auditors receiving or reviewing the Confidential Information... are hereinafter referred to as the 'Recipients'.
High Priority.problem: The definition of 'Recipients' is too narrow. It omits key personnel such as consultants, shareholders, and potential syndicate members, which is required by the playbook to ensure operational flexibility.
High Priority.suggested_replacement: Confidential Information may be disclosed by the Undersigned to its affiliates and its and their respective directors, officers, employees, consultants, advisers, shareholders, potential syndicate members, agents, representatives, and other providers of financing (collectively, "Representatives"), who need to know such information for the Transaction, provided that the Undersigned shall be responsible for any breach of this Undertaking by its Representatives.

High Priority.citation: ...on first written request by the Company, the Undersigned will within five business days at its option (i) return or (ii) destroy all Confidential Information and as far a reasonable practicable, permanently destroys all other data carriers...
High Priority.problem: The clause mandates the destruction of information without providing the necessary exceptions for data retained in automated backup systems, for legal or regulatory compliance, or as part of internal work product ('Secondary Information').
High Priority.suggested_replacement: Upon the Company's written request, the Undersigned shall return or destroy all Confidential Information. However, this obligation shall not apply to: (i) Confidential Information that the Undersigned or its Representatives must retain under any applicable law, rule or regulation, including the rules of a professional body and good corporate governance practice; (ii) Confidential Information and elaborations thereof as have been saved to electronic carriers under automatic archiving or data security procedures; and (iii) reports, notes or other materials prepared by or on behalf of the Undersigned which incorporate Confidential Information ('Secondary Information'). Any Confidential Information or Secondary Information that is not returned or destroyed shall remain subject to the confidentiality terms of this Undertaking.

High Priority.citation: ...to induce any of the suppliers or customers of the Company to change or terminate their business relationship with the Company, except in the ordinary course of business and unrelated to the Transaction;
High Priority.problem: This clause is an overly broad restriction on interfering with all suppliers and customers. The playbook only permits a narrow non-solicitation clause targeting the counterparty's key representatives or investment managers.
High Priority.suggested_replacement: For a period of one/two (1/2) year from the date of this Undertaking, the Undersigned agrees not to solicit any representative or investment manager of the Company with whom it had contact in relation to the Transaction, and agrees not to persuade any such representative or investment manager to terminate or adversely alter its relationship with the Company.

High Priority.citation: ...not initiate or have discussions with respect to prospective employment (conditions) of any directors, officers or key employees of the Company during a period of 24 (twenty four) months starting on the date of this Undertaking.
High Priority.problem: The non-solicitation of employees clause fails to exempt Strada's affiliated portfolio companies from its restrictions, which is a mandatory requirement under the playbook.
High Priority.suggested_replacement: For a period of one/two (1/2) year from the date of this Undertaking, the Undersigned agrees not to directly solicit for employment any employee of the Company with whom the Undersigned had material contact in connection with the Transaction. This restriction shall not apply to any of the Undersigned's affiliated portfolio companies, nor shall it apply to employees who respond to general public advertisements, make an unsolicited application for employment, are referred by a third-party recruiter who was not instructed to target the Company's employees, or whose employment was terminated by the Company.

High Priority.problem: The agreement is silent on the limitation of liability. This absence exposes the Undersigned to potentially unlimited liability, including for indirect, consequential, special, or punitive damages, which is prohibited by the playbook.
High Priority.suggested_replacement: Liability for a breach of this Undertaking shall be limited to proven, direct damages. In no event shall either party be liable for any indirect, consequential, special, punitive, or incidental damages, or for any loss of profits, revenue, or data.

Medium Priority.citation: ...not (i) to contact (by whatever means) the Company, its direct or indirect shareholders, their management, their current or former key employees, agents, advisors, auditors or representatives in connection with the Transaction...
Medium Priority.problem: The no-contact clause is overly broad. It restricts contact with a wide range of parties, including shareholders and former employees, whereas the playbook requires this restriction to be narrowly tailored to directors, officers, or employees directly involved in the transaction.
Medium Priority.suggested_replacement: Without the prior written consent of the Company, the Undersigned agrees not to contact any directors, officers, or employees of the Company in connection with the Transaction. This restriction shall not be breached by any contact made for another purpose than the purpose of evaluating and negotiating the Transaction.

Low Priority.citation: Confidential Information excludes any information that: a) at the time of its disclosure it was already in the public domain... d) it was already lawfully in your possession prior to such disclosure.
Low Priority.problem: The definition of Confidential Information is missing standard market exceptions. Specifically, it fails to exclude information received from a third party without a confidentiality obligation and information disclosed with permission.
Low Priority.suggested_replacement: Confidential Information does not include information that: (a) is or becomes generally available to the public through no breach by Undersigned of the confidentiality undertakings hereunder; (b) was in Undersigned's lawful possession before receipt from the Company, without any obligation of confidentiality owed to the Company; (c) was received in good faith by Undersigned from a third party that is not subject to an obligation of confidentiality owed to the Company; or (d) was disclosed by Undersigned pursuant to the written permission of a duly authorized representative of the Company.

Low Priority.citation: ...each of the Recipients has given a statement in writing to the Undersigned to accept and fully comply... with the obligations of the Undersigned under this Undertaking as its own...
Low Priority.problem: The agreement imposes strict liability on the Undersigned for any breach by its Representatives. The playbook prefers an 'efforts-based' standard to limit liability for the actions of external parties.
Low Priority.suggested_replacement: The Undersigned will use its best efforts to procure that each of its Representatives who receives any Confidential Information is aware of and adheres to the terms of this Undertaking. The Undersigned shall be responsible for any breach of the confidentiality obligations of this Undertaking by its Representatives.

Low Priority.citation: This Undertaking is governed by Dutch law and the Court of Amsterdam will have exclusive jurisdiction to settle any dispute...
Low Priority.problem: The agreement specifies Dutch law and Amsterdam courts. While this is an acceptable European jurisdiction, it deviates from the playbook's primary preference for Belgian law and the exclusive courts of Antwerp, Belgium.
Low Priority.suggested_replacement: This Undertaking, and any contractual or non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with it, shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of Belgium. Any disputes arising out of or in connection with this Undertaking shall be submitted to the exclusive jurisdiction of the competent courts in Antwerp, division Antwerp, Belgium.

hr_edits_data.citation: Context: '...professional advisers, providers of finance, ++[shareholders, potential syndicate members]++ and auditors receiving or reviewing the Confidential Information...'
hr_edits_data.problem: The definition of 'Recipients' was expanded to include 'shareholders, potential syndicate members'. This is a positive change that aligns with High Priority Policy 2, which requires a broad definition of who can receive confidential information to facilitate consortium bids and financing.

hr_edits_data.citation: Context: '...comply vis-à-vis the Undersigned and, the Company with the obligations of the Undersigned under this Undertaking as its own ++[, except where expressly stated otherwise in this Undertaking,]++ and (ii) that none...'
hr_edits_data.problem: An exception was added allowing for Representatives to not be fully bound by the Undertaking if 'expressly stated otherwise'. This creates a potential loophole that could weaken Strada's responsibility for its Representatives, which contradicts the spirit of Policy 2 and Policy 13. The playbook requires Strada to be responsible for breaches by its Representatives.

hr_edits_data.issue: Correction aligning with High Priority Policy 3
hr_edits_data.citation: Context: '...permanently destroys all other data carriers... ++, [except for (i) Confidential Information...saved to electronic carriers under automatic data archiving... (ii) reports, notes or other materials...('Secondary Information')... and (iii) Confidential Information which is required to be retained for...compliance purposes];++'
hr_edits_data.problem: Exceptions were added to the return/destruction clause. This is a critical correction that aligns with High Priority Policy 3, which mandates that Strada must be permitted to retain information stored on automated backup systems, contained in internal work product, and required for legal/regulatory compliance.

hr_edits_data.issue: Correction aligning with Medium Priority Policies 6 & 13
hr_edits_data.citation: Original: '...during a period of 24 months... notify and [cause] each of the Recipients not to contact...' New: '...during a period of [12] (twelve) months... notify and use its best efforts to cause each of the Recipients not to contact...'
hr_edits_data.problem: The clause was modified in two ways. First, the restricted period for the no-contact/no-inducement clause was reduced from 24 to 12 months, which is well within the 2-year maximum allowed by Policy 5. Second, the standard of liability was softened from a strict 'cause' to 'use its best efforts to cause', which aligns with the preference for an efforts-based standard in Low Priority Policy 13. Both are positive changes.

hr_edits_data.issue: Correction aligning with High Priority Policy 4
hr_edits_data.citation: Original: '...advertisement not specifically directed at any employee... which is published in a national, regional or trade newspaper, magazine or on the Internet... during a period of 24 months...' New: '...advertisement not specifically directed at any employee... during a period of 12 (twelve) months...'
hr_edits_data.problem: The non-solicitation of employees clause was improved. The term was reduced from 24 to 12 months, compliant with Policy 4's 2-year maximum. Additionally, the restrictive language specifying where a general advertisement could be published was removed, broadening the exception for general hiring and making it more favorable to Strada, in line with the spirit of Policy 4.

hr_edits_data.issue: Violation of Medium Priority Policy 8 and Golden Rule
hr_edits_data.citation: Context: '...period of 24 (twenty four) months from the date of this Confidentiality Agreement. ++[This undertaking does not impose an obligation on the Undersigned to enter into definitive agreements regarding the Transaction]. ++ This Undertaking is governed by...'
hr_edits_data.problem: A 'No Commitment' clause was added. While the language itself is acceptable, Medium Priority Policy 8 and the Golden Rule explicitly state not to add such a clause if one is not already present. The goal is to keep the NDA concise and minimize Strada's contractual statements. This addition violates that principle.

hr_edits_data.issue: Correction aligning with Low Priority Policy 11
hr_edits_data.citation: Original: '...governed by Dutch law and the Court of Amsterdam will have exclusive jurisdiction...' New: '...governed by [Belgian] law and the [courts of Antwerp, division Mechelen] will have exclusive jurisdiction...'
hr_edits_data.problem: The governing law and jurisdiction were changed from Dutch law/Amsterdam courts to Belgian law/Antwerp courts. This is a positive change that brings the clause into perfect alignment with Strada's preferred position as stated in Low Priority Policy 11.

hr_edits_data.citation: Context: '[The entire clause was deleted] --With respect to all matters set forth in the Undertaking, it is understood that: (i) this Undertaking sets forth the intentions... and (ii) that no Party shall be responsible for any claims or liability...-- In furnishing the Confidential Information...'
hr_edits_data.problem: A clause functionally equivalent to a 'No Commitment' clause was deleted from the disclaimer. This deletion aligns with the 'Golden Rule of NDA Review' which prefers concise agreements by removing unnecessary clauses. This is a positive change, although it is contradicted by the addition of a similar clause in Section B.
